field_edited_text.value:
Planning for the Valley began in 1902. The Municipal Art
Society, an organization devoted to civic betterment, and
newly created by Theodore Marburg, retained the Olmsted
Brothers, the top landscape architects of that era, to make a
report on the development of public grounds in Baltimore.
Their report, published in 1904, continues to this day as the
framework for open space and park planning for Baltimore
City and its environs. The Approved Park Plan of the City is
based upon the Olmsted Plan as updated by that firm in 1926.

Much of the Olmsted Plan was realized by the City. Herring
Run Park in East Baltimore and Gwynn’s Falls Park in West
Baltimore are substantially complete. The third major stream-
valley system recommended by the Olmsteds for Jones Falls
Valley, serving the north and northwest part of the City, has
never been completed.

Today, active construction on the Jones Falls Expressway has
refocused attention on this forgotten valley. The amazing
fact is that a tremendous amount of open land still exists. It
seemed more important than ever that the Valley, through
which some 65-70,000 Baltimore motorists would travel daily,
be studied to determine its future.

As a result, the Board of Recreation and Parks of the City of
Baltimore, and the same Municipal Art Society, authorized the
Planning Council of the Greater Baltimore Committee to
explore the proper land uses, and development potential of
the Valley. Major emphasis was to be on the possibility of
carrying out the early park concept.

While the 1904 report proposed a continuous park from Mary-
land Avenue to Lake Roland, the 1926 proposal eliminated
the strip park south of Bend Hill, the north side of Woodberry.
This represented a weakening of the concept. On detailed
study the continuity of the Valley’s park-like character was
seen to be essential from Penn Station to Lake Roland and on
to the Beltway. Interrupt this continuity at any point, and the
concept will cease to have validity.

Though detailed analysis in the present study was limited to

the area between Penn Station and the city line, it is obvious

that the Valley’s significance — both as a City landmark and
regional geographic feature — does not stop at these points.
South to the harbor, an extension of green could be placed
along the edges of the expressway as the continuity of the
concept and as a pleasant, visual edge for Downtown. North
of the city line, the connection into Lake Roland is absolutely
necessary for the pedestrian linkage to this City-owned, 450-
acre park. The Scenic Road, utilizing existing Falls Road
north to the Prettyboy Reservoir, is still unspoiled and a great
opportunity for the taking.



In 1904 the Olmsted Brothers had a plan for Jones Falls Valley.
